newsitem.title: UK: British back outsiders in Oscars race.
newsitem.headline: British back outsiders in Oscars race.

text.p: British bookmakers cut the odds on Friday of outsider Billy Bob Thornton winning the best actor Oscar at the Academy Awards ceremony on Monday but Geoffrey Rush in "Shine" is still the clear favourite.
Ladrokes's are offering 5-1, slashed from 20-1, on Thornton for his role as a mentally disabled man in "Sling Blade" while Rush's portrayal of a tortured Australian pianist in "Shine" is 8-11 on.
"Geoffrey Rush has been a favourite even before the Oscar nominations came out," Ladbrokes spokesman Simon Clare said.
In the best film category "The English Patient", is the front-runner at 1-6 on while "Shine" at 11-2 and "Fargo" at 7-1 are a distant second and third.
"Jerry Maguire" at 10-1 and "Secrets & Lies" at 25-1 are the other films nominated for best picture. "In terms of what we've been taking 'The English Patient' is a certainty," said Clare.

The big surprise has been in the best actress category where Frances McDormand's pregnant policewoman in "Fargo" at 4-9 on, is favoured over Kristin Scott Thomas (4-1) in "The English Patient" and Brenda Blethyn's Golden Globe award-winning performance in "Secrets & Lies." Blethyn is quoted at 3-1.
"People just wanted to back her at any price. It's clearly become apparent that it's Frances McDormand," said Clare.
